content: I'm trying to learn the category theory library. Why do I not get told what the keyboard shortcuts for ùüô (the identity morphism) and ùü≠ (the identity functor) are, when I hover over them in VS Code? NB ùüô is \b1 but I can't seem to find the other one in https://github.com/leanprover/vscode-lean/blob/master/translations.json which is where I usually look on the rare occasion when this happens.
And another thing: hovering over ‚âà in VS Code gives Type ‚âà using ~~ ... and it should be \~~

I'm bumping this because I'm doing category theory again. I still literally do not know how to type ùü≠ in VS Code! I always have to open a file in the category theory library and cut and paste. VS Code hover doesn't work for me. The other two issues seem to have been resolved.
Indeed, the hover is correct. There is no way to type it.
Is it just missing an entry in translations.json, or is this a weird unicode thing?
I think we've covered all relevant Unicode weirdnesses by now. It's just missing an entry in the translations.json file.
https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib/blob/726d83f1baed16426c9fbeca93bcc82412736b39/src/category_theory/functor.lean#L57
This is a quick and easy change. But I don't know what the abbreviation should be. \id?
Is there some convention for bold characters? e.g. I needed ùïç for the first time recently and just knew it was going to be \bbV. But I've never used any bold characters.
Is this MI stuff both bold and italic? (link to translations.json is in my first post, I'm on line 1350 or so)
Is there a reason we have bold italic capitals but no bold capitals?

The MI characters appear to be the "Mathematical Bold Italic" characters from the "Mathematical Alphanumeric Symbols‚Äù code block. That block also includes ùü≠ near the very end, and it's apparently called "Mathematical Sans-Serif Bold Digit One". There's a different character "Mathematical Bold Digit One" which looks like this: ùüè.

I think I'll just PR the Sans-Serif Bold digits for now. Does anyone have any strong feelings about the prefixes, or would sb1 be OK for ùü≠?

Note that b1 is already in use in translations.json for the blackboard-bold digits (what Unicode calls "Mathematical Double-Struck").

PR here.
What???? Unicode contains six different characters for the number 1? 1ùüèùüôùü£ùü≠ùü∑
How many does it include for the number 6?
That's not even counting the circled variant ‚ë† as well as superscripts, subscripts...
Maths has more I think -- we can do 1111^{1^1}111 and so on
I think each one is a bit smaller than the one below. Reminds me of the cat in the hat came back.
OK so it turns out that there is no notation for the identity natural transformation -- @Scott Morrison which 1 do you want to use for it? I rather like ‚ë†.
I think you're just supposed to use the identity morphism (since a natural transformation is a morphism)

If I hover over ‚ü∂ then VS Code tells me I can type it with \hom or \--> or \r-- or \longrightarrow, but in the category theory files in mathlib Scott casually remarks that one should typeset it with \h (which works fine!)
I might need to import something before a natural transformation becomes a morphism?
import category_theory.functor_category? (not at a computer)
Thanks. So strictly speaking this is a lie. I'm not sure any of those notations work once you've imported that file!
maybe we should merge those files, or at least move the category instance
Yes, that's true. Shall I just move the category instance to avoid this problem?
I don't see a particular problem with merging them entirely.
